page.title: 15ARCHITECTURE 2
page.content: The oldest houses at Stourmouth pre- date the Tudor's. They are built of {Caen stone}and flints, and the walls of the lower stories have a{'chequer {board'}appearance. Timber framed buildings are common although some have had an outer skin of red brick added, and so look much more modern than they are. There are also example of Post-Tudor buildings in red brick with{'Flemish Gables".}Perhaps the finest buildings in the district are Georgian, with one superb farmhouse. Victorian and later houses and farm buildings are dotted about, so that during a walk through Stourmouth you can see every stage in vernacular architecture, from the{14th Century}to the present day.
